prompt:
Let
$$f(x)=\frac{x^2-9}{x-3}$$
for $x\ne 3$. Which value of $f(3)$ makes $f$ continuous at $x=3$?
latex:
Let
$$f(x)=\frac{x^2-9}{x-3}$$
for $x\ne 3$. Which value of $f(3)$ makes $f$ continuous at $x=3$?

options.explanation: This equals $x$ at $x=3$, but the simplified expression is $x+3$, not $x$.
Setting $f(3)=0$ does not match the limiting value of $f(x)$ as $x\to 3$.
Since $\frac{x^2-9}{x-3}=x+3$ for $x\ne 3$, the limit as $x\to 3$ is $6$.

options.text: Does not exist (cannot be made continuous)
options.explanation: A removable discontinuity at $x=3$ can be removed by defining $f(3)$ to equal the limit.

explanation: Factor $x^2-9=(x-3)(x+3)$. For $x\ne 3$, $f(x)=x+3$. Therefore $\lim_{x\to 3} f(x)=3+3=6$. Define $f(3)=6$ to make $f$ continuous at $x=3$.

micro_explanations.B: Chooses an arbitrary fill-in value instead of matching the limit.
micro_explanations.C: Matches $f(3)$ to the limit at the hole.
micro_explanations.D: Misclassifies a removable discontinuity as non-removable.

recommendation_reasons: Targets removing a removable discontinuity by redefining a point value.
Reinforces safe canceling with domain awareness.
title: C13-Q1 Fill the Hole by Defining f(3)

prompt:
Define
$$g(x)=\begin{cases}
\frac{x^2-1}{x-1}, & x\ne 1 \\
 k, & x=1
\end{cases}$$
Which value of $k$ makes $g$ continuous at $x=1$?
latex:
Define
$$g(x)=\begin{cases}
\frac{x^2-1}{x-1}, & x\ne 1 \\
 k, & x=1
\end{cases}$$
Which value of $k$ makes $g$ continuous at $x=1$?

options.explanation: The limit as $x\to 1$ is not $0$.
For $x\ne 1$, $\frac{x^2-1}{x-1}=x+1$, so the limiting value at $x=1$ is $2$.
This equals the point $x=1$, but continuity requires matching the function value to the limit.
The discontinuity is removable, so a suitable $k$ exists.

explanation: Factor $x^2-1=(x-1)(x+1)$. For $x\ne 1$, $g(x)=x+1$. Thus $\lim_{x\to 1} g(x)=2$. Continuity at $x=1$ requires $k=2$.

micro_explanations.A: Common when substituting $x=1$ into the numerator only.
micro_explanations.B: Correctly uses the simplified form and matches $k$ to the limit.
micro_explanations.C: Confuses the input value with the function value needed for continuity.
micro_explanations.D: Treats a removable discontinuity as non-removable.

recommendation_reasons: Builds the continuity condition $\lim g(x)=g(1)$ in piecewise form.
Practice factoring and canceling to evaluate limits at holes.
title: C13-Q2 Choose k for Continuity at x=1

prompt:
Let
$$h(x)=\begin{cases}
\frac{x^2-4}{x-2}, & x<2 \\
 ax+b, & x\ge 2
\end{cases}$$
If $h$ is continuous at $x=2$ and $h(3)=7$, what are $a$ and $b$?
latex:
Let
$$h(x)=\begin{cases}
\frac{x^2-4}{x-2}, & x<2 \\
 ax+b, & x\ge 2
\end{cases}$$
If $h$ is continuous at $x=2$ and $h(3)=7$, what are $a$ and $b$?

options.explanation: This satisfies continuity at $x=2$ but does not satisfy $h(3)=7$.
Continuity at $x=2$ requires $2a+b=4$, and $h(3)=7$ requires $3a+b=7$; solving gives $a=3$, $b=-2$.
This makes $h(3)=6$, not $7$.
This makes $h(3)=4$, not $7$.

explanation: For $x<2$, $\frac{x^2-4}{x-2}=x+2$ (for $x\ne 2$), so $\lim_{x\to 2^-}h(x)=4$. Continuity at $x=2$ (using the $x\ge2$ branch) gives $h(2)=2a+b=4$. Also $h(3)=3a+b=7$. Subtract: $(3a+b)-(2a+b)=7-4\Rightarrow a=3$. Then $2(3)+b=4\Rightarrow b=-2$.

micro_explanations.B: Correctly sets up two linear equations from continuity and the given value.
micro_explanations.C: Solves only one condition or makes an arithmetic slip.
micro_explanations.D: Treats the right branch as constant due to misreading.

recommendation_reasons: Integrates removable-discontinuity limit with piecewise continuity constraints.
AP-style parameter solve with two conditions.
title: C13-Q4 Continuity + Point Value Determines Line

prompt: For the function $$f(x)=\frac{5x^3-2x+7}{2x^3+9},$$ what is the horizontal asymptote of the graph of $f$?
latex: For the function $$f(x)=\frac{5x^3-2x+7}{2x^3+9},$$ what is the horizontal asymptote of the graph of $f$?

options.explanation: This confuses end behavior at infinity with a slant asymptote rule; equal degrees do not produce a linear asymptote.
Correct: degrees are equal, so the horizontal asymptote is the ratio of leading coefficients $\frac{5}{2}$.
This is true only when the numerator degree is less than the denominator degree.
There is a horizontal asymptote because the degrees are equal.

explanation:
As $x\to\pm\infty$, the highest-degree terms dominate:
$$f(x)=\frac{5x^3-2x+7}{2x^3+9}\sim\frac{5x^3}{2x^3}=\frac{5}{2}.$$
So the horizontal asymptote is $y=\frac{5}{2}$.

micro_explanations.C: Would require numerator degree < denominator degree.
micro_explanations.D: Rational functions always have end behavior asymptote (horizontal/slant) based on degrees.

recommendation_reasons: Reinforces the degree/leading-coefficient rule for limits at infinity of rational functions.
notes: Focus: horizontal asymptote for equal-degree rational functions.
title: U1C15_Q1_HorizontalAsymptote_EqualDegrees

prompt:
Find the horizontal asymptote of
$$f(x)=\frac{\sqrt{x^2+4x+1}}{x}$$
(if it exists).
latex:
Find the horizontal asymptote of
$$f(x)=\frac{\sqrt{x^2+4x+1}}{x}$$
(if it exists).

options.explanation: The numerator grows like $|x|$, not like a constant.
Correct: for large $|x|$, $\sqrt{x^2+4x+1}\sim |x|$, so the ratio behaves like $|x|/x$.
This ignores that $\sqrt{x^2+4x+1}\sim |x|$, not $x$.

options.text: No horizontal asymptote in either direction
options.explanation: The function approaches constants (possibly different) as $x\to\infty$ and $x\to-\infty$.

explanation:
Rewrite by factoring $x^2$ inside the square root:
$$\frac{\sqrt{x^2(1+4/x+1/x^2)}}{x}=\frac{|x|\sqrt{1+4/x+1/x^2}}{x}=\frac{|x|}{x}\,\sqrt{1+4/x+1/x^2}.$$
As $x\to\infty$, $\frac{|x|}{x}=1$ and the square-root factor $\to 1$, so the limit is $1$.
As $x\to-\infty$, $\frac{|x|}{x}=-1$ and the square-root factor $\to 1$, so the limit is $-1$.
Thus the end behavior approaches $y=1$ to the right and $y=-1$ to the left.

micro_explanations.D: Limits are finite constants in both directions.

recommendation_reasons: Targets a common AP trap: square roots at infinity introduce $|x|$ and can yield different horizontal asymptotes.
notes: Advanced end behavior with radicals; distinguishes $x$ vs $|x|$.
title: U1C15_Q5_HorizontalAsymptote_RadicalOverX
